thread.title: St. Paul police threaten arrests to prevent marathon disruption
thread.title_full: St. Paul police threaten arrests to prevent marathon disruption - StarTribune.com

author: Kevin Duchschere
title: St. Paul police threaten arrests to prevent marathon disruption
text:
St. Paul police will keep all options on the table — including arrests — to prevent Black Lives Matter from disrupting Sunday’s Twin Cities Marathon and stopping runners from finishing the race, city leaders said Wednesday.
Mayor Chris Coleman issued a statement saying that while the city backs the rights of citizens to peaceful protest, the group’s expressed intent to interfere with the popular annual event poses “an unacceptable risk to runners, spectators and protesters themselves.”
Coleman was not specific about what kind of action the police might take to ensure the marathon goes as planned.
At a media briefing at police headquarters early Wednesday afternoon, St. Paul Police Chief Thomas Smith also declined to provide details on how police plan to respond to any disruption on the St. Paul part of the 26.2-mile race that starts in Minneapolis and finishes near the State Capitol.
But Smith said that police “will not tolerate any action which compromises the marathon” and warned anyone who might disrupt the event that “there will be consequences, including arrests.”
Smith said that not once in the 33 years that St. Paul police have been involved in providing security for the marathon has the event “been disrupted....and we’re not going to see that occur now.
“We’ll ensure that they will finish the race,” Smith said of the runners, adding that his department is committed to protecting the rights of the protesters, but not at the expense of the safety of runners in the marathon.
“My message to runners and spectators is to ‘Go out and enjoy the day,’ ” Smith said.
St. Paul City Attorney Sammy Clark, standing alongside Smith, said the earlier protests by Black Lives Matter at the State Fair and along the Green Line “are not the same” as a possible disruption of the marathon, which follows a set course that will be bounded by thousands of spectators.
“We’ve shown the ability to respect the rights of protestors,” Clark said of previous actions that did not result in arrests because public safety was not at risk. “But this is different.”
Earlier Wednesday, St. Paul police spokesman Steve Linders said that the department was “taking steps to ensure the event is safe and a success for all runners, spectators and everyone in the community who has put so much time and effort into the event. We respect people’s rights to make their voices heard, but not at the expense of others.”
The St. Paul chapter of Black Lives Matter has said it plans to shut down the event near the finish line at the State Capitol to raise awareness of recent incidents involving St. Paul police and people of color.
Coleman said that he had reached out to group leaders hoping to meet with them before Sunday. He said that he wanted to get a better sense of what the group is asking the city and police to do to address its concerns.
City officials are reviewing incidents cited by the group’s leaders, he said.
“I … believe it is important for leaders of Black Lives Matter to understand the extraordinary efforts Chief Smith and the department have taken to address issues of racial equity,” Coleman said.
The mayor noted that while recent demonstrations have disrupted traffic and blocked access to the State Fair, they haven’t led to serious injuries or arrests. He said the police had done “an exceptional job” of balancing protest rights with public safety.
Rashad Turner, an organizer of Black Lives Matter St. Paul, said in a text message later Wednesday that a meeting with Coleman is scheduled for Thursday.
James Walsh contributed to this report.
